required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on July 28, 2020
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Evaluation of Breathing Effort in Spontaneously Breathing Subjects
clinical_study.official_title: Problems of Measurement and Evaluation of Breathing Effort in Spontaneously Breathing Subjects

brief_summary.textblock:
The aim of the research project is to evaluate the breathing effort using the Work of Breathing (WoB) and Pressure-Time Product (PTP) parameters, depending on the increasing flow resistance. The research project is concerned with assessing the increased (imposed) breathing effort using the Work of Breathing (iWoB) and the Pressure-Time Product (iPTP).
The main hypothesis tested is the differential effect of flow resistance on iWoB and iPTP parameters in spontaneous breathing of healthy probands.

detailed_description.textblock: Due to the different calculation of iWoB and iWoB, these parameters may be affected at higher flow resistance values. The proposed experiment will be used to compare iWoB and iPTP obtained during spontaneous breathing to healthy subjects.

study_design_info.intervention_model_description: In the experiment, the proband will breathe through the D-Lite measuring screen of the Datex-Ohmeda S/5 Patient Monitor patient monitor (GE, USA). Unlike clinical practice, an adjustable flow resistance will be connected to the system. The flow resistance is set by adjustable by a removable diaphragm with different hole diameters according to the intended flow resistance.

primary_outcome.time_frame: through study completion, an average of 1 year
primary_outcome.description: imposed work of breathing in J/s/L

primary_outcome.time_frame: through study completion, an average of 1 year
primary_outcome.description: imposed pressure time product in Pa.s/L

arm_group.arm_group_label: Breathing through a system with adjustable flow resistance
arm_group.description: During the experiment, the volunteers will breathe through ten adjustable flow resistances and their work of breathing will be measured.

intervention.intervention_name: Breathing through a system with adjustable flow resistance
intervention.description: The proband will breathe through the adjustable flow resistance within the experiment, to which a standard D-lite Flow sensor will be connected, and the airway pressure, flow, minute consumption, oxygen and carbon dioxide, tidal volume, oxygen saturation of peripheral blood and oxygen and carbon dioxide concentrations in both inspired and expired air will be recorded using the Datex-Ohmeda S/5 Patient Monitor vital signs monitor. The proband will breathe through the flow resistors in a randomized order, and pre-defined three-minute pauses will be maintained between measurements with different flow resistance values. Each measurement will take approximately two minutes and will be measured on ten different flow resistances.
intervention.arm_group_label: Breathing through a system with adjustable flow resistance

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Healthy males and females > 18 and < 40 years old
- Signed informed consent has been obtained
Exclusion Criteria:
- Respiratory disease
- Pregnancy
- Cardiovascular disease
- Diabetes mellitus

overall_official.affiliation: Czech Technical University in Prague, Fac. of Biomedical Engineering

facility.name: Department of Biomedical Technology Faculty of Biomedical Engineering Czech Technical University in Prague

reference.citation: Bellani G, Pesenti A. Assessing effort and work of breathing. Curr Opin Crit Care. 2014 Jun;20(3):352-8. doi: 10.1097/MCC.0000000000000089. Review.

de Vries H, Jonkman A, Shi ZH, Spoelstra-de Man A, Heunks L. Assessing breathing effort in mechanical ventilation: physiology and clinical implications. Ann Transl Med. 2018 Oct;6(19):387. doi: 10.21037/atm.2018.05.53. Review.
Dodd DS, Kelly S, Collett PW, Engel LA. Pressure-time product, work rate, and endurance during resistive breathing in humans. J Appl Physiol (1985). 1988 Apr;64(4):1397-404.
Collett PW, Perry C, Engel LA. Pressure-time product, flow, and oxygen cost of resistive breathing in humans. J Appl Physiol (1985). 1985 Apr;58(4):1263-72.
Cabello B, Mancebo J. Work of breathing. Intensive Care Med. 2006 Sep;32(9):1311-4. Epub 2006 Jul 13. Review.

patient_data.ipd_description: Anonymous data from anesthesia monitor of vital functions
